Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Sustainable phosphorus recovery from agricultural waste

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512429 (Blaney) and 1511399 (Sengupta)

Waste streams have traditionally been considered as a source of pollutants to environmental systems. Poultry litter has been a topic of recent interest due to high nutrient loads in runoff from agricultural areas. Moving forward, a paradigm shift is needed to reconsider waste streams from a resource recovery perspective. The overall aim of this project is to investigate a hybrid technology that allows for continuous-flow treatment of poultry litter and high recovery of phosphorus. By shifting nutrient loading issues into potential resource/revenue streams, progress in reducing nutrient loads to sensitive ecosystems can be accelerated. This goal will be pursued through partnership with Triea Technologies, a company focused on agricultural sustainability.

The hypothesis of this research is that phosphorus can be sustainably recovered from concentrated poultry litter slurries using a two-phase process. This process consists of a Phosphorus Extraction and Recovery System (PEARS), which allows for phosphorus release from poultry litter and subsequent precipitation as a high-value product, and a hybrid ion exchange, Hydrated Ferric Oxide - Polymeric Ligand Exchanger (HFO-PLE) unit that polishes PEARS effluent to ensure low-phosphorus effluent. The hypothesis will be tested through study of the following specific objectives: Objective 1: Optimize and model the process chemistry for PEARS to produce struvite and potassium struvite from poultry litter. Objective 2: Achieve additional phosphorus recovery from PEARS effluent using specialty
polymeric ligand exchangers impregnated with hydrated ferric oxide. Objective 3: Determine the purity of the recovered phosphorus product and explore the sustainable reuse of extraction and regeneration solutions. Objective 4: Determine potential nutrient load reductions in the Chesapeake Bay watershed and development a start-up program for a PEARS-HFO-PLE pilot. The generation of high-value phosphorus-based fertilizers from poultry litter would be an important advancement in the environmental-agricultural field. The approach to coupling the PEARS and HFO-PLE systems will ensure process effluent has low phosphorus content. The project will leverage ongoing relationships with the Meyerhoff Scholars Programs, which primarily serves African American students, to engage and mentor undergraduate students in research. The research team will engage farmers and agricultural communities to describe the benefits of phosphorus recovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wastewater treatment plants and agricultural operations both introduce nutrients into water bodies, but the nutrient loads from regions with intensive agricultural practices often drive negative environmental outcomes. Passive agricultural waste management strategies, such as piling, composting, and lagooning, have been adopted by animal feeding operations to treat organic carbon and nitrogen. However, these practices do not achieve any significant phosphorus removal. The fate of phosphorus in agricultural systems is a growing concern due to increased eutrophication of inland water bodies. Compounding this issue, natural phosphorus reserves are being rapidly depleted due to food demand from the growing global population. Together, the environmental effects of phosphorus pollution and the economic vulnerability of phosphorus markets mandate a need for phosphorus recovery from agricultural waste.

In this context, poultry operations are especially important due to the high phosphorus content in poultry litter compared to other animal manures. This situation raises environmental concerns about nutrient runoff from fields amended with poultry litter. The State of Maryland, which contains dense poultry operations, recently limited the use of poultry litter as a soil amendment on over 10,400 acres of land to decrease phosphorus inputs to the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The initial economic impact model suggested that up to 228,000 tons of poultry litter would require active management under these new regulations. To address this problem, we developed an innovative technology to extract phosphorus out of poultry litter and recover value-added fertilizers that could be sold in other regions.

The overall goal of this project was to build an academic liaison with an industry focused on advancing phosphorus recovery from agricultural waste in order to (i) offset negative environmental outcomes from nutrient pollution and (ii) ensure food and economic security by generating a sustainable phosphorus supply. We hypothesized that phosphorus could be efficiently recovered from concentrated poultry litter using a two-step process. This process consisted of the Phosphorus Extraction and Recovery System (PEARS), which released phosphorus from poultry litter and precipitated this important nutrient as a high-value product, and a hybrid polymeric exchange unit that polished PEARS effluent to ensure low-phosphorus effluent. The specific objectives were as follows:

  1. Optimize and model the process chemistry for PEARS to produce struvite and potassium struvite fertilizers from poultry litter;
  2. Achieve additional phosphorus recovery from PEARS effluent using specialty polymeric ligand exchangers impregnated with hydrated ferric oxide;
  3. Determine the purity of the recovered phosphorus product and explore the sustainable reuse of extraction and regeneration solutions; and,
  4. Determine potential nutrient load reductions in the Chesapeake Bay watershed and develop a start-up program for the two-step process.

Each objective generated intellectual merit related to the state of knowledge on nutrient recovery from agricultural waste. In Objective 1, we comprehensively examined extraction of phosphorus, nitrogen, potassium, and other ions from poultry litter using CO2(g). Following extraction, the low-nutrient litter was separated from the nutrient-rich solution. The nutrient-rich solution was bubbled with air to release the dissolved CO2(g), and then the pH was adjusted to approximately 9.0. These steps resulted in the formation of value-added struvite fertilizers. In Objective 2, the process effluent from above was passed through a specialty adsorbent to remove residual phosphorus. This important step increased the overall phosphorus recovery and decreased the phosphorus levels in the final process effluent. In Objective 3, all process steps were systematically investigated to not only increase nutrient recovery and product purity, but also improve operation efficiency and decrease waste volume. In Objective 4, we developed, operated, and optimized a pilot-scale reactor to recover nutrients from larger batches of poultry litter. This pilot reactor was crucial to a licensing agreement signed with Ostara Nutrient Recovery Technologies to transfer the technology into the public sector.

The broader impacts of the project were focused on (i) education, training, and professional development of students and (ii) engagement with farmers and the agricultural community about nutrient recovery. Two PhD students, one MS student, and six BS students were involved with the project; furthermore, three of these students were African American, four of the students were women, and one of the students had a disability. These students conducted experimental activities associated with the intellectual merit described above. All nine students presented their work at regional, national, or international conferences. The PI also conducted outreach to various campus organizations, including the Center for Women in Technology, the Meyerhoff Scholars Program, and the Office of Undergraduate Education. The aims of the outreach activities were to inspire, encourage, and guide students to undergraduate research opportunities. We worked closely with farmers to collect poultry litter, discuss our experimental findings, and highlight the motivation and results from this project in print articles. Ultimately, this collaborative project provided the following benefits to society: reduced nutrient pollution of water supplies; increased national food security; decreased hypoxia in lakes, rivers, and estuaries; and, revenue generation.
